channel.title: Posts on Hi there!
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on Hi there!

item.title: Radar Scattering Prediction
item.description: I organized SnowEx 2022 hackweek in collaboration with NASA. During the hackweek, I also worked on a project of “Radar Scattering Prediction” About the project This project aims to estimate the backscattering of radar from snowpits using parameters from SnowEx data such as density, temperature, grain size and height. We are also trying to understand the relationship between these input parameters and the backscatter and evaluate the parameter sensitivity. And want to explore the link between SnowEx pit measurements and input parameters of DMRT-Bic.
item.content:
I organized SnowEx 2022 hackweek in collaboration with NASA. During the hackweek, I also worked on a project of “Radar Scattering Prediction”

About the project

This project aims to estimate the backscattering of radar from snowpits using parameters from SnowEx data such as density, temperature, grain size and height. We are also trying to understand the relationship between these input parameters and the backscatter and evaluate the parameter sensitivity. And want to explore the link between SnowEx pit measurements and input parameters of DMRT-Bic. Another cool thing would be to see if there is a correlation between the SWE and the amplitudes.

Why did we work on this project?

Currently, we know that there is backscatter when a radar is directed towards snow but we do not know what variables of the snow actually have an impact on this backscatter and how much impact each of these parameters have on it. This is is the problem we are trying to solve using Machine Learning. In the broader context, the inference of the relationship between input parameters and the amplitude can help us calibrate current sensor tools and also to be used to reverse engineer when the satellites are up in the air.

Read about my experience of organizing this hackweek here and if this project is of interest to you too, follow this link to read more about the project or just get the code!

item.title: Mind Reading using Artificial Intelligence
item.description: About the project Human communication works by turning thought into motion. However, sometimes it would be really handy if we could communicate directly from our brain. Studies on brain imaging show that different spatial patterns of neural activation are associated with thinking about different semantic categories of words and so we have attempted to “Mind Read” by applying machine learning algorithms on data from functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) reports to predict the category of words that a person may be thinking of.
item.content:
About the project

Human communication works by turning thought into motion. However, sometimes it would be really handy if we could communicate directly from our brain. Studies on brain imaging show that different spatial patterns of neural activation are associated with thinking about different semantic categories of words and so we have attempted to “Mind Read” by applying machine learning algorithms on data from functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) reports to predict the category of words that a person may be thinking of.

Why did we work on this project?

The brain has been a mystery for generations. The authors of the project have always been curious to understand how the human brain works, how it perceives images and other senses and how it functions so wonderfully. Now finally, we are in an age where we can understand the underlying functioning of the neural structures within the brain and make an attempt to piece together why humans respond to situations the way they do. I and my project partner, Anuhya are from a Computer Science Background and the science of the brain has awed us. This project gives us an opportunity to combine our area of study (Artificial Intelligence) to our area of interest (Neuroscience) and this is our main motivation behind taking up this project.

If this is of interest to you too, follow this link to read more about the project or just get the code!

item.title: Restaurant Visitor Forecasting
item.description: About the project La Pino’z Pizza is India’s fastest growing and the most popular Pizza chain. The first pizzeria opened up in Chandigarh in 2011 and now there are more than 350 outlets across India. A few of these outlets belong to my father. Even though this is a very up and coming, new generation Pizza place in India, I have seen first hand how the business works - the same old traditional way.
item.content:
About the project

La Pino’z Pizza is India’s fastest growing and the most popular Pizza chain. The first pizzeria opened up in Chandigarh in 2011 and now there are more than 350 outlets across India. A few of these outlets belong to my father. Even though this is a very up and coming, new generation Pizza place in India, I have seen first hand how the business works - the same old traditional way. This project is motivated out of personal curiosity and a desire to suggest that these businesses can profit a lot more if they analyze the data that is generated on a daily basis and use the insights from this analysis in a fruitful way. “Currently, few restaurants use R or any other readily available statistical software to analyze their data. Instead many use subscriptions to services that may preform basic analysis such as averaging and then display that information in basic, though visually appealing visualizations.” This is exactly what I wanted to fix by the medium of this project.

Two of the most important aspects in functioning of any restaurant is number of visitors and total sales. Forecasting the sales and number of visitors is an essential component in the decision-making process for the owners of these restaurants. For this reason, I tried to investigate the performance of the sales and visitors for 2 different restaurants of the same La Pino’z franchise. This project aims at analyzing the time series models of sales for at least 2 restaurants and number of visitors for at least 2 restaurants.

Why did I work on this project?

I am interested in this project because I have seen this business function very first hand and if by the concepts learnt during my time at UW, there is something that I could add to it that helps the business grow, I would be happy to help my family business.

item.title: The Pac-Man Projects
item.description: About the projects The Pac-Man projects were developed for UC Berkeley’s introductory artificial intelligence course, CS 188. They apply an array of AI techniques to playing Pac-Man. They teach foundational AI concepts, such as informed state-space search, probabilistic inference, and reinforcement learning. These concepts underly real-world application areas such as natural language processing, computer vision, and robotics. Why did I work on these projects? The projects allowed me to visualize the results of the techniques they implement.
item.content:
About the projects

The Pac-Man projects were developed for UC Berkeley’s introductory artificial intelligence course, CS 188. They apply an array of AI techniques to playing Pac-Man. They teach foundational AI concepts, such as informed state-space search, probabilistic inference, and reinforcement learning. These concepts underly real-world application areas such as natural language processing, computer vision, and robotics.

Why did I work on these projects?

The projects allowed me to visualize the results of the techniques they implement. They also contain code examples and clear directions, but do not force me to wade through undue amounts of scaffolding. Finally, Pac-Man provides a challenging problem environment that demands creative solutions; real-world AI problems are challenging, and Pac-Man is too.

Project 1: Search

I implemented depth-first, breadth-first, uniform cost, and A* search algorithms. These algorithms are used to solve navigation and traveling salesman problems in the Pacman world.

link to the code

Project 2: Multi-Agent Search

Classic Pacman is modeled as both an adversarial and a stochastic search problem. I implemented multiagent minimax and expectimax algorithms, as well as designed evaluation functions.

link to the code

Project 3: Reinforcement Learning

I implemented value iteration and Q-learning. And tested the agents first on Gridworld (from class), then applied them to a simulated robot controller (Crawler) and Pacman.

link to the code

Project 4: Machine Learning

This project was an introduction to Machine Learning problems like digit classification, language identification, and algorithms like perceptron, non-linear regression.

link to the code

item.title: Statistical Analysis of News Articles
item.description: About the project Social media is a real world phenomenon of the saying “If the tree falls on the ground and no one is around to hear it, does it make a sound?” Mashable, an independent news platform, is a part of this social media world providing the latest news articles on digital culture, social media and technology. However, not every new article is a hit, and our group aims to find what makes an article popular by analyzing various factors related to the article.
item.content:
About the project

Social media is a real world phenomenon of the saying “If the tree falls on the ground and no one is around to hear it, does it make a sound?” Mashable, an independent news platform, is a part of this social media world providing the latest news articles on digital culture, social media and technology. However, not every new article is a hit, and our group aims to find what makes an article popular by analyzing various factors related to the article.

Why did we work on this project?

As news and media shifts online, it provides us with an opportunity to ask and answer questions about readers and publishers, thanks to the data trail it leaves behind. This analysis can shed some light on how individuals consume online news, what are the various factors that affect their engagement with it and how have news publishers like NYT and Mashable have evolved over time to keep their audience engaged.

If this is of interest to you too, follow this link to read more about the project or just get the code!

item.title: Unsupervised Learning Approaches for Dimensionality Reduction and Data Visualization
item.description: Why this book was written? Dimensionality reduction is a mainstay of modern data analysis - a black box that is widely used but sometimes poorly understood. I, along with my co-authors, Dr. Tripathy and Anveshritha aim to dispel the magic behind this blackbox. This book focuses on building a solid intuition for how and why Unsupervised learning algorithms work for Dimensionality reduction. We attempted to crystallize this knowledge by deriving from simple intuitions, the mathematics behind all the algorithms.
item.content:
Why this book was written?

Dimensionality reduction is a mainstay of modern data analysis - a black box that is widely used but sometimes poorly understood. I, along with my co-authors, Dr. Tripathy and Anveshritha aim to dispel the magic behind this blackbox. This book focuses on building a solid intuition for how and why Unsupervised learning algorithms work for Dimensionality reduction. We attempted to crystallize this knowledge by deriving from simple intuitions, the mathematics behind all the algorithms.

About the book

Unsupervised Learning Approaches for Dimensionality Reduction and Data Visualization describes such algorithms as Locally Linear Embedding (LLE), Laplacian Eigenmaps, Isomap, Semidefinite Embedding, and t-SNE to resolve the problem of dimensionality reduction in the case of non-linear relationships within the data. Underlying mathematical concepts, derivations, and proofs with logical explanations for these algorithms are discussed, including strengths and limitations. The book highlights important use cases of these algorithms and provides examples along with visualizations. Comparative study of the algorithms is presented to give a clear idea on selecting the best suitable algorithm for a given dataset for efficient dimensionality reduction and data visualization.

Features of the book

  • Demonstrates how unsupervised learning approaches can be used for dimensionality reduction
  • Neatly explains algorithms with a focus on the fundamentals and underlying mathematical concepts
  • Describes the comparative study of the algorithms and discusses when and where each algorithm is best suitable for use
  • Provides use cases, illustrative examples, and visualizations of each algorithm
  • Helps visualize and create compact representations of high dimensional and intricate data for various real-world applications and data analysis

Who should read this book?

This book is aimed at professionals, graduate students, and researchers in Computer Science and Engineering, Data Science, Machine Learning, Computer Vision, Data Mining, Deep Learning, Sensor Data Filtering, Feature Extraction for Control Systems, and Medical Instruments Input Extraction.

If you are interested in learning more about these concepts, buy it from here or get it from Amazon.
